headline: Gingrich: 'Attack mode' works better for Trump than Clinton
subHeadline: Former House Speaker and presidential candidate Newt Gingrich goes 'On the Record' on Hillary Clinton's blistering attack against Donald Trump in foreign policy speech, its potential impact and what it means in the road to November.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, 'ON THE RECORD' GUEST HOST
utterances.sentences: Batting off, leading off, for us tonight, former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich goes ON THE RECORD. Always a pleasure to have you here ON THE RECORD and on "Fox." if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb2', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb2', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } So, wow, just so you know, that was labeled a foreign policy speech by Hillary Clinton. Your thoughts. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban2', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban2', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: NEWT GINGRICH, FORMER SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: Well, look, I think you are getting a taste of what the next couple of months are going to be like. She is going to pound on Trump. Trump is going to pound on her. We're all going to get sick of it. It's unfortunate, but I think that's the direction the campaign is going to go in. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb3', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb3', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } There are huge disagreements over legitimate policy. It would be tempting to see the two of them try for a week to just talk about their policy disagreements. But I don't think they can. I think she is totally drawn to attacking him as a person. He is totally drawn to counter attacking her as a person. And that leads you to sort of, I think, a discouragingly negative and not particularly useful campaign. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban3', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban3', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } One of them may turn out to be the less unliked, but it won't be a very good way to run the country.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: If you were advising Secretary Clinton, what would you have told her to do in that foreign policy speech? Would you say lay out some specifics and stay away from personal attacks? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb4', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb4', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.sentences: I actually would say to her that for the next two months, she ought to focus on a positive vision of a better America and a better future. She has an opportunity to try to define how she would be different from Obama and how clearly she is different from Trump. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb3', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb3', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban4', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban4', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } But the country -- the young people are going to Sanders are going to Sanders in part because they are repelled by Clinton's entire style and her negativity, et cetera. And Donald Trump hit her on the fact that, you know, she has got her DNA directly tied to the failed foreign policy and failed national security of President Barack Obama. And she was there for it as secretary of state.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.sentences: Of course. Well, and that's one of her challenges. Look, if she gets sucked in to defending the past. She is going to get killed. I mean, my favorite story is this Russian reset button, her very first meeting with the Russian foreign minister. Well, and, by the way, if you look at what happened to Governor Walker in Wisconsin, you had better expect left wing protesters and a certain amount of left wing intimidation because when Walker introduced his reforms in February of 2011, they ended up with 100,000 people in Madison.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, 'ON THE RECORD' GUEST HOST
utterances.utterance: Batting off, leading off, for us tonight, former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich goes ON THE RECORD. Always a pleasure to have you here ON THE RECORD and on "Fox." So, wow, just so you know, that was labeled a foreign policy speech by Hillary Clinton. Your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: NEWT GINGRICH, FORMER SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.utterance: Well, look, I think you are getting a taste of what the next couple of months are going to be like. She is going to pound on Trump. Trump is going to pound on her. We're all going to get sick of it. It's unfortunate, but I think that's the direction the campaign is going to go in. There are huge disagreements over legitimate policy. It would be tempting to see the two of them try for a week to just talk about their policy disagreements. But I don't think they can. I think she is totally drawn to attacking him as a person. He is totally drawn to counter attacking her as a person. And that leads you to sort of, I think, a discouragingly negative and not particularly useful campaign. One of them may turn out to be the less unliked, but it won't be a very good way to run the country.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: If you were advising Secretary Clinton, what would you have told her to do in that foreign policy speech? Would you say lay out some specifics and stay away from personal attacks?

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.utterance: I actually would say to her that for the next two months, she ought to focus on a positive vision of a better America and a better future. She has an opportunity to try to define how she would be different from Obama and how clearly she is different from Trump. But the country -- the young people are going to Sanders are going to Sanders in part because they are repelled by Clinton's entire style and her negativity, et cetera. And she doesn't need, you know, she doesn't need to attack Trump as intensely as she is right now. Trump is going to be around. He is not going to change much. She could take him on starting around September 1st and do just fine. But if she is this negative this early, and he is this negative this early, my hunch is that his personality actually wears better in an attack mode than hers does.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Now, specifically, though, if she was to focus on her foreign policy accomplishments and achievements, many of the critics say what could she tout, in fact? And Donald Trump hit her on the fact that, you know, she has got her DNA directly tied to the failed foreign policy and failed national security of President Barack Obama. And she was there for it as secretary of state.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.utterance: Of course. Well, and that's one of her challenges. Look, if she gets sucked in to defending the past. She is going to get killed. I mean, my favorite story is this Russian reset button, her very first meeting with the Russian foreign minister. For some idiotic reason her staff goes and gets the button off the whirlpool of the hotel, which is a red button. They paint what they thought in Russian what was restart. It turned out that it actually was overcharge. Because the translator got it wrong. They give it to the Russian foreign minister who breaks out laughing and says no, we are not going to pay an overcharge. I mean, nothing captured better the childishness and the incompetence of the Clinton secretary of state than her effort to reset stupidly. Now, I don't think she is going to win a fight over the recent past. If she got sucked into defending Libya, defending Benghazi, defending Syria, defending what she has done with Russia, she is just going to end up getting beaten into the ground.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's really a problem. And then you tie in, of course, the email server, the private server scandal, the refusal to turn over emails, the deletion, et cetera, all impinging upon national security. They are highly problematic for her. It just seems that there is some legitimate grievances that the American people might have with her suitability as a potential commander-in-chief.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.utterance: Which, of course, what makes her attack on Trump about whether or not he is suitable to be commander-in-chief kind of goofy. I think that the challenge we've got and it's a really sad challenge is right now these two candidates are rushing into a campaign to see which one we dislike least, because we're going to end up disliking both of them. And the question is going to be on election day holding your nose and deciding, OK, I have to be "X," because I can't be for "Y." I just think as a citizen, that's not a very good way to run the country.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No. That's the problem. So they are going a little bit back and forth. But I think this is a good indicator of how things are going to be, you know, going forward is a little bit of a taste test about the general election. But a lot more and as you see, of course, the protesters, violence erupting, so emotions are running high, speaker.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.utterance: That's right. Well, and, by the way, if you look at what happened to Governor Walker in Wisconsin, you had better expect left wing protesters and a certain amount of left wing intimidation because when Walker introduced his reforms in February of 2011, they ended up with 100,000 people in Madison.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.utterance: Now, Wisconsin is not that big of state. You take that and project it on to the city of Washington, you could imagine a Trump presidency, a million people brought in by the unions and you can imagine over the next few months how hostile some of these outside crowds are going to be just as happened in San Jose.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, both sides, I think, need to send a strong message that violence will not be tolerated. Speaker, always a pleasure to have you. Thanks for joining us tonight.

utterances.speaker: GINGRICH
utterances.utterance: Good to be with you. Thank you.
